page.name: Enhancing Learner Persistence (Video)
page.intro:
Research suggests that educational programs characterized by learner-centered approaches in which students’ diverse learning preferences are addressed have increased likelihood of retaining students. In fact, when the focus is student learning, colleges have been shown to attain higher rates of student retention and have better prepared graduates than those students who were more traditionally trained (Sternberg & Grigorenko, 2002). Although many of these studies address the relationship between learner-centeredness and persistence in higher education, there also is some evidence that the same holds true for adult education. The background reading in this course by Comings, Perrella, and Soricone (2000) reports that learners are more likely to persist in adult education programs that 
  • Reinforce learner self-efficacy by providing “regular recognition of progress and celebrations of achievement”; 
  • “Take great care to develop a culture of support among students”; and
  • Help students to “set learning goals and…measure their progress toward goals.”

The above are all principles of SCL.
